questions.text: A 62-year-old presented with diminished vision 1 year after cataract surgery. The findings are shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The given clinical vignette supported with the image of vacoulated clusters seen behind IOL is suggestive of Elschnig’s pearls which is a type of after cataract.
After cataract also known as secondary cataract or posterior capsular opacification is a late postoperative complication that follows extracapsular extraction of the lens.

questions.text: Defect at the level of the optic chiasma will result in which of the following visual field defects?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Lesions at the level of the optic chiasma cause bitemporal hemianopia.
The Nasal fibers of each retina decussate at the optic chiasma. Hence, a lesion at this level affects the temporal quadrants of both eyes.

questions.text: A 60-year-old diabetic male presents with a history of decreased vision. Fluorescein angiography showed the following image. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The given clinical vignette and Fluorescein angiography findings of neovascularization are suggestive of proliferative diabetic retinopathy (PDR).
Neovascularization is a hallmark of PDR. So this rules out Non-proliferative diabetic retinopathy-NPDR (Option A,B).
Option C: Birdshot retinochoroidopathy is an idiopathic bilateral chorioretinitis characterized by creamy yellow spots of chorioretinal hypopigmentation resembling a birdshot scatter. It dshot seatter most commonly affects middle aged females who are HLA-A29 positive. Aged feme
PDR is most common in patients with Type I diabetes after a period of 15-20 years and is characterized by proliferation of new vessels at the optic disc (NVD) or elsewhere in the fundus (NVE).

questions.text: A patient presents with endophthalmitis 5 days after cataract surgery. All of the following treatments can be used, except
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

Intravenous steroids steroids are not used for the treatment of endophthalmitis.
Endophthalmitis is defined as an intraocular inflammation that predominantly affects the inner spaces of the eye and their contents, i.e. the vitreous and/or the anterior chamber. The cardinal features of endophthalmitis are pain, swelling of the lid and diminished vision. Once the endophthalmitis sets in it is important to treat all the cases empirically with a combination of antibiotics and steroids from the beginning.

questions.text: A patient presents with unilateral ptosis with hypotropia in the same eye. He was given an IV injection, following which the symptoms go away. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Only Myasthenia gravis among the conditions mentioned above, would show dramatic improvement after administration of an IV injection like Anti-Cholinesterase, edrophonium.

questions.text: A patient recently underwent LASIK surgery for his myopia. He is now complaining of headaches and eye pain. Identify the test being performed on him.
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The above image is of the dynamic contour tonometer such as the Pascal tonometer. The dynamic contour tonometer(Pascal) offers a non-invasive and direct method of intraocular pressure (IOP) measurement with an additional measurement of the ocular pulse amplitude. This type of tonometer is unaffected by the corneal thickness and it is the tonometer of Lasik patients.

questions.text: A patient came to the ophthalmology OPD with corneal abrasion, corneal ulcer, corneal perforation and foreign body. Which of the following will not cause hypotonic maculopathy in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Suprachoroidal haemorrhage will not cause hypotonic maculopathy in this patient.
Maculopathy is common in eyes developing hypotony, which is defined as IOP less than 6 mmHg. The most common cause is excessive drainage following glaucoma filtration surgery(option D). Other causes include trauma such as cyclodialysis of uvea (option B), penetrating injury (option C), chronic uveitis, retinal detachment and other systemic causes such as dehydration, uncontrolled diabetes, uraemia and treatment with hyperosmotic agents. They usually cause bilateral hypotonic maculopathy.

questions.text: The physician noticed the following finding in a patient that came to the OPD for an eye exam. What is the most likely diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The given image of the patient shows ptosis of the right eye. Ptosis is abnormal drooping of the upper eyelid to a level that covers more than 2mm of the superior cornea, it commonly occurs due to paralysis or defective development of the levator palpebrae superioris (LPS).

questions.text: A 55-year-old male patient came to OPD with the complaints of glare during night drives. He had undergone cataract surgery 1 year back. The best-corrected visual acuity is RE = 6/12 and LE = 6/9. No improvement with pinhole. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The given clinical picture of a post cataract surgery patient coming with symptoms of glare and reduced visual acuity which doesn’t improve on pinhole testing is suggestive of posterior capsular opacification (PCO).
Pinhole testing is done to differentiate between the various causes of reduced visual acuity. On pinhole testing if the visual acuity remains the same or worsens it is suggestive of either a macular disease or posterior capsular opacification.

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy was brought with the complaints of protrusion of the right eye with no h/o fever. CT Scan showed a well-defined mass in the orbit with an irregular border and adjacent bony destruction. Biopsy showed small, round cells which were positive for Desmin in Immunohistochemistry. What is the probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The clinical scenario of a patient with complaints of protrusion of eye with well-defined mass in the orbit and adjacent bony destruction on CT scan and biopsy showing small, round cells positive for Desmin favors rhabdomyosarcoma.

questions.text: A 30-year-old man presents with a history of injury to the eye caused by a leaf 5 days ago, resulting in pain, photophobia, and redness of the eye for 2 days. What would be the most likely pathology?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The given clinical vignette of the patient presenting with pain, photophobia and redness of the eye following trauma by a vegetative matter is suggestive of fungal corneal ulcer.

Fungal corneal ulcer also known as Mycotic Keratitis is usally caused by trauma from vegetative matter such as branches of trees, leaves and animal tails. Injudicious use of topical steroids and antibiotics increase the predisposition to develop secondary fungal keratitis.

questions.text: A 6-year-old girl is admitted for evaluation for recurrent seizures. She has a large port-wine stain on the right side of her face as shown below. The MRI of the head shows a leptomeningeal angioma. What is the most common ocular manifestation of the underlying condition?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The given clinical picture of a young child presenting with unilateral port wine stain in the region of trigeminal nerve supply and leptomeningeal angioma as seen on MRI is indicative of Sturge-Webber syndrome (SWS). Glaucoma is the most common ocular manifestation of SWS.
Sturge weber syndrome is a neurocutaneous disorder(phakomatoses) that is characterized by unilateral capillary malformation at the region of trigeminal supply known as port wine stain or nevus flammeus, ipsilateral diffuse cavernous hemangioma of the choroid and ipsilateral leptomeningeal hemangiomatosis, which causes seizures and mental retardation.

questions.text: A 26-year-old female patient presents with 6/60 visual acuity in one eye and 6/18 in the other eye. She has recurrent episodes of diminution of vision which recovers on treatment with steroids. She also has a history of transverse myelitis. What is the most probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (C)

The given clinical viginette of a patient presenting with decreased visual acuity and a history of transverse myelitis which is treated with steroids is indicative of Neuromyelitis optica (NMO).

questions.text: A patient presents to the emergency and his ocular examination reveals the following. Which of the following is not done initially?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The above image shows penetrating injury by a metallic fish-hook.
In cases of penetrating injuries, the foreign body is removed only after ascerting it’s location through a CT scan.
Hence, Removal of the foreign body is not done initially in these injuries. It is surgically explored & repaired under OT settings

choices.text: When he complains of decrease in vision

questions.text: A person is diagnosed to have diabetes on his 45th birthday. When will you recommend a dilated fundus examination for him?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

A 45 year old diagnosed with diabetes mellitus is likely to be type 2 diabetes and he should undergo screening for diabetic retinopathy immediately at the time of diagnosis.
Duration of diabetes is the most important risk factor for developing diabetic retinopathy especially proliferative diabetic retinopathy

questions.text: A patient with a history of diabetes and hypertension underwent fundus fluorescent angiography (FFA) to evaluate his decreasing vision. The FFA yields an image as shown below, which is characteristic of:
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

The Fundus fluorescent angiography (FFA) image shows enlarged foveal avascular zone which is seen as hypofluorescent patch in the macula(white arrow), with surrounding capillary non perfused areas (blue arrow) both of which are suggestive of macular ischemia.

questions.text: A patient presents with left-sided head tilt which on straightening leads to right hypotropia. This increases on dextroversion and right head tilt. Paralysis of which of the following muscles is involved?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (B)

The given clinical scenario is suggestive of right superior rectus palsy.
The Park’s-Bielschowsky three-step test is employed to diagnose the muscle paralysis responsible for vertical eye deviation.

questions.text: A patient underwent LASIK for myopia and now is undergoing cataract surgery. What is the formula used for lens power calculation in this patient?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

Among the given options, the Haigis-L regression formula is used for calculating the lens power in a patient who is undergoing cataract surgery with a previous history of refractive surgery.
Haigis formula uses Axial Length (L), Corneal curvature (K), and Anterior Chamber Depth (ACD) for the calculation of IOL power (biometry).

questions.text: Which of the following pupillary abnormalities is most likely to be observed in a patient with primary open-angle glaucoma?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (A)

Primary open-angle glaucoma commonly causes bilateral and asymmetric optic nerve damage. Marcus Gunn pupil also known as relative afferent pupillary defect (RAPD) is the earliest sign of optic nerve disease as seen in optic nerve neuritis or primary open-angle glaucoma(POAG).
RAPD is caused due to a defect in the afferent pathway (optic nerve) of the pupillary light reflex in one eye.

questions.text: A 30-year-old female presents with redness and pain in the eye. Examination revealed an IOP of 38 mm of Hg, aqueous flare, and corneal precipitates. Which of the following drugs must be avoided in her?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer (D)

The given clinical vignette is suggestive of anterior uveitis with a raised intraocular pressure. Among the given options, latanoprost is the least suited for use in this patient as it can result in worsening of the anterior uveitis.
